Commerce Server 2006: Beta 1 Illustrated Configuration Guide

Posted by jefflynch on January 28, 2006

I’ve decided to update this post since the beta installation docs have changed. Please read the install docs thoroughly before installing the Commerce Server 2006 Beta bits. Follow ALL the instructions and it will work! Skip a step or two and you’ll spend the next few hours or days saying #$%^ over and over again.


After you install the Commerce Server 2006 Beta, you use the Configuration Wizard to enter the local or domain user accounts and the corresponding passwords for the Direct Mailer Service and the Administration database. You also use the Configuration Wizard to configure the Reporting Service for Commerce Server Staging.


A few quick points to remember:



  • Make sure SQL Server 2000 or 2005 is up and running before starting the Configuration Wizard.
  • When asked by the Configuration Wizard for the name of the SQL Server DO NOT USE “localhost”, use the instance name.
  • You MUST use the Local User Account setup during the installation to run the Commerce Server 2006 Beta under!

Start the Configuration Wizard by running the :\Program Files\Microsoft Commerce Server 2006\CSConfig.exe executable.



  1. On the Welcome screen click Next



  2. On the Administrative Database page type in the name of your SQL instance and select Windows Authentication. Click on the Test button to test your connection and then on the Next button to proceed.



  3. On the Staging Service page, select Configure Reporting Service for Commerce Server Staging to configure IIS for the Staging Reporting Service and then add local user account previously setup to run this service under. You should be using the <Computer name>\CSWPA account for this. Click Next to proceed.



  4. On the Marketing Direct Mailer page type in the name of your SQL instance and select Windows Authentication. Then add the local user account previously setup to run this service under. You should be using the <Computer name>\CSWPA account for this. Click Next to proceed.



  5. On the Summary page, review the components you’ve just configured. Click Next to proceed. You can also save this configuration as an XML file by clicking on the Save button.



  6. Now sit back and watch the pretty progress bar (or not).



  7. After the configuration finishes, you can review the log file (or not) and then click on the Microsoft Commerce Server Deployment Roadmap to learn how to deploy Commerce Server.



  8. Download the new Starter Site and extract it to a folder.


  9. Unpack the Starter Site Pup using the Quick Unpack option. After unpacking is finished, to review the list of events in the Site Packager log file, click View Log File.


  10. Import the sample data by running SampleDataImport.exe \Inetpub\Wwwroot\StarterSite from a command prompt.


  11. Extract the catalog images from the \Program Files\Microsoft Commerce Server 2006\SDK\Samples\Catalog folder, and right-click the AdvWorksImages.zip file, and then click Extract All. Select the destination as \Inetpub\Wwwroot\StarterSite\Images.


IT’S EXTREMELY IMPORTANT THAT YOU RUN ALL THE POST-INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS SHOWN IN THE INSTALLATION GUIDE IF YOU WANT THE COMMERCE SERVER 2006 BETA TO RUN CORRECTLY!


Sorry for shouting but if you don’t run all the required post-installation steps you’ll spend the next few days in a state of ever increasing frustration. Send me an email via my blog if you get stuck on this part.

    Martyn,

    A few things to check.

    Make sure you are logged on to your server using a local (or domain) admin account so you have sufficient priviledges to install CS2006 and unpack a site.

    Make sure you have installed and configured ASP.NET 2.0 correctly by running aspnet_regiis from a command prompt.

    If this doesn’t work send me an email via my blog and I’ll try to help you sort things out.

  9. Max Akbar says:
    December 30, 2005 at 12:52 am

    Hi Jeff,

    Nice job on the blogs. I wanted to shed some light on your comment about the “Note: I have absolutely no idea what this reporting service is. Sounds pretty interesting though!”

    Commerce Server 2006 comes with a new feature “Commerce Server Staging” CSS for short. You can stage Commerce Data like Catalogs, Marketing, Orders Configuration, Site Terms, and content files. When CSS stages its data or content we call it Projects CSS needs to logs its data somewhere (CSS can log its project status in local Access DB, Event log or email). By default most of the events are logged into the Access DB and to view the status of the projects IIS needs to be configured to allow administrators to view reports. So that’s what this is.

    Regards,
    -Max
